Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the decrease in the positivity rate from 13% in June to 4.4% in September, as the actual decrease was from 13% to 8% in August.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the positivity rate was only reached at 13% in July, not in June as stated by the President.
Falters at times: The claim falters in accurately representing the timeline and figures related to the positivity rate.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient support or evidence to back up the President's figures and statements.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that reaching a 5% positivity rate is the only recommendation by the WHO to guide the reopening of an economy, which experts argue is not the case.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim acknowledges that other factors must be considered in addition to the positivity rate when deciding to reopen the economy.
